Efficient quantum repeater in perspectives of both entanglement concentration rate and LOCC complexity

Zhaofeng Su Centre for Quantum Software and Information, University of Technology Sydney, Ultimo NSW 2007, Australia.    Ji Guan Centre for Quantum Software and Information, University of Technology Sydney, Ultimo NSW 2007, Australia.    Lvzhou Li Institute of Computer Science Theory, School of Data and Computer Science, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, 510006, China
Abstract

Quantum entanglement is an indispensable resource for many significant quantum information processing tasks. However, because of the noise in quantum channels, it is difficult to distribute quantum entanglement over a long distance in practice. A solution for this challenge is the quantum repeater which can extend the distance of entanglement distribution. In this scheme, the time consumption of classical communication and local operations takes an important place in perspective of time efficiency. Motivated by this observation, we exploit the basic quantum repeater scheme in perspectives of not only the optimal rate of entanglement concentration but also the complexity of local operations and classical communication. Firstly, we consider the case where two two-qubit pure states are prepared. We construct a protocol with the optimal entanglement concentration rate and less consumption of local operations and classical communication. We also find a criteria for the projective measurements to achieve the optimal probability. Secondly, we exploit the case where two general pure states are prepared and general measurements are considered. We get an upper bound on the probability for a successful measurement operation to produce a maximally entangled state without any further local operations.

I Introduction

In the last three decades, quantum computation and quantum information has become one of the most active research fields. Many significant quantum information processing protocols have been proposed NL00 . Remarkable progress has been achieved in both theoretical and experimental aspects. For example, quantum teleportation for sending an unknown quantum bit CB93 , quantum key distribution for quantum cryptography PS00 , and quantum dense coding for communicating two bits by sending only one qubit which is the inverse of quantum teleportation CB92 ; KM96 . As the most basic and counterintuitive characteristics of quantum mechanics, quantum entanglement plays an indispensable role in all the above applications.

The first step towards the implementation of these applications is to distribute quantum entanglement over remotely located participants. However, there are two bottlenecks for directly sending quantum states over long distance NC11 . On one hand, the probability of absorption when transmitting a photon increases exponentially with the distance. For example, the 1 km long fiber has a transmission of 95%percent9595\% while the rate of 1000km fiber is 10−10superscript101010^{-10} Hz which means transmitting a photon successfully every 300 years. On the other hand, even when a photon arrives at the destination, the fidelity of the transmitted state decreases exponentially with the distance because of the noise in quantum channels.

A solution for this problem is to use quantum repeaters to divide the long distance into many shorter segments. Each of the segments has tolerable probability for absorption and noise. The first protocol of quantum repeaters was proposed by Briegel HW98 , and experimental progresses have been made since then ZT03 ; AW03 .

In the basic scenario of quantum repeater, two copies of a bipartite quantum state ρ𝜌\rho are shared by three participants, say Alice, Clare and Bob. Alice and Clare share the copy ρA​Csubscript𝜌𝐴𝐶\rho_{AC}, and Clare and Bob share ρC​Bsubscript𝜌𝐶𝐵\rho_{CB}. By performing local operations and classical communication (LOCC) between these three parties, quantum entanglement can be created between Alice and Bob, thereby extending the distance of entanglement distribution. The basic scenario is depicted in Fig 1.

This basic scenario is also known as quantum entanglement swapping ZM93 . Bose et al. considered the case where the same two-qubit pure states are prepared in each segments SV98 . They found the optimal strategy of quantum swapping in the perspective of concentrating the most entanglement between Alice and Bob. Shi et al. considered the case where different two-qubit pure states are prepared BY00 . In their strategy, Clare performs a projective measurement in the standard Bell basis. Then, Alice and Bob perform local operations to create maximally entangled state between them. Shi et al. found out that the optimal entanglement concentration rate is exactly the same as the concentration rate of the scenario where the less entangled one resource is directly distributed between Alice and Bob. Hardy and Song considered the case where general entangled pure states are distributed in a chain scenario LD00 . Several groups have experimentally demonstrated entanglement swapping CT09 ; XC16 .

In the basic quantum repeater scheme, the protocol consists of preparation of quantum resources and LOCC. In practice, quantum resources can be efficiently transmitted over a short distance NC11 . Once the quantum resources are prepared, entanglement could be concentrated from the scenario by applying LOCC. Therefore, it is of practical significance to consider the LOCC complexity in the protocol.

In this work, we exploit the basic quantum repeater scheme in perspectives of both entanglement concentration rate and LOCC complexity. Firstly, we exploit the scenario where two different two-qubit pure states are prepared. We construct a protocol which can create entanglement between Alice and Bob with the optimal rate and less consumption of LOCC resources. We also find a criteria for the projective measurements which are able to achieve the optimal rate of entanglement concentration. Secondly, we exploit the scenario where two different higher dimensional pure states are prepared and general measurements are considered. We get an upper bound on the probability for a successful measurement operation to produce a maximally entangled state between Alice and Bob without any further local operations.

II Taking different two-qubit pure states as resource

In this section, we consider the case where two different pure states of a two-qubit system are prepared in the basic quantum repeater configuration. We construct a protocol to concentrate maximally entangled two-qubit state between Alice and Bob with the optimal entanglement concentration rate and less LOCC complexity.

Any pure state of a two-qubit system can be expressed as |Φθ⟩≡cos⁡θ​|00⟩+sin⁡θ​|11⟩,θ∈[0,π2]formulae-sequenceketsubscriptΦ𝜃𝜃ket00𝜃ket11𝜃0𝜋2|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle\equiv\cos\theta|00\rangle+\sin\theta|11\rangle,\theta\in[0,\frac{\pi}{2}] up to a local unitary on either party. Note that local unitary operations cannot affect quantum entanglement which is a kind of resource that could not be created or increased with LOCC. Thus, we only need to consider the case that the entangled states |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle and |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle with θ,η∈(0,π4]𝜃𝜂0𝜋4\theta,\eta\in(0,\frac{\pi}{4}] are initially distributed in the configuration which is depicted in Fig. 2.

Lemma 1.

Suppose two parties share a two-qubit state |Φλ⟩=cos⁡λ​|00⟩+sin⁡λ​|11⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜆𝜆ket00𝜆ket11|\Phi_{\lambda}\rangle=\cos{\lambda}|00\rangle+\sin{\lambda}|11\rangle with λ∈(0,π2)𝜆0𝜋2\lambda\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2}). By performing LOCC, the state can be probabilistically transferred into a maximally entangled state. The probability of the successful transformation is upper bounded by PE​(Φλ)≡min⁡{2​cos2⁡λ,2​sin2⁡λ}subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜆2superscript2𝜆2superscript2𝜆P_{E}(\Phi_{\lambda})\equiv\min\{2\cos^{2}\lambda,2\sin^{2}\lambda\}.

Lemma 1, which is an implication of Vidal’s result GV99 , gives the upper bound on the entanglement concentration rate of the scenario where an entangled two-qubit state |Φλ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜆|\Phi_{\lambda}\rangle is shared by two parties. With out loss of generality, suppose cos⁡λ≥sin⁡λ𝜆𝜆\cos{\lambda}\geq\sin{\lambda}. The upper bound concentration rate could be achieved by performing a general measurement {M0,M1}subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1\{M_{0},M_{1}\}, where M0=tan⁡λ​|0⟩​⟨0|+|1⟩​⟨1|subscript𝑀0𝜆ket0bra0ket1bra1M_{0}=\tan{\lambda}|0\rangle\langle 0|+|1\rangle\langle 1| and M1=1−tan2⁡λ​|0⟩​⟨0|subscript𝑀11superscript2𝜆ket0bra0M_{1}=\sqrt{1-\tan^{2}{\lambda}}|0\rangle\langle 0|, on either party. If the measurement outcome 00 was observed, the maximally entangled state would be created between them. The corresponding probability is PE​(Φλ)=2​sin2⁡λsubscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜆2superscript2𝜆P_{E}(\Phi_{\lambda})=2\sin^{2}{\lambda}.

By applying Lemma 1, we get the upper bound on the entanglement concentration rate for the simplest quantum repeater scenario depicted in Fig. 2, which is concluded in the following lemma.

Lemma 2.

Suppose that the two-qubit states |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle and |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle are initially distributed in the scenario depicted in Fig. 2. Let PM​Ssubscript𝑃𝑀𝑆P_{MS} be the optimal probability that maximally entangled state can created between Alice and Bob by applying LOCC. Then, PM​S≤min⁡{PE​(Φθ),PE​(Φη)}subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{MS}\leq\min\{P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}),P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta})\}.

Proof.

We prove this lemma via deducing contradictions. Suppose PM​S>PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{MS}>P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}). Then, we consider a scenario where the resource |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle is shared by Alice and Bob. Further, let Bob locally prepare an ancilla state |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle. According to the definition, the probability of creating maximally entangled state between Alice and Bob by applying LOCC is PM​Ssubscript𝑃𝑀𝑆P_{MS}, which is greater than PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}). This result contradicts with Lemma 1. Thus, the assumption is not true. It should have PM​S≤PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{MS}\leq P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}). Similarly, we can get PM​S≤PE​(Φη)subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{MS}\leq P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta}). Therefore, we have PM​S≤min⁡{PE​(Φθ),PE​(Φη)}subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{MS}\leq\min\{P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}),P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta})\}. ∎

In our protocol, we consider a projective measurement on Clare’s joint system. A successful projection of Clare is the one when maximally entangled state could be directly created between Alice and Bob without any further local operations. Our strategy is to construct a projective measurement such that the sum of the probabilities of the successful projections is as high as possible. For the projections that result Alice and Bob in less entangled states, we can apply the probabilistic entanglement concentration by performing a local measurement operation on Bob’s system. In general, we can concentrate entanglement from the scenario with high probability and less LOCC complexity.

In the following lemma, we work out the lower and upper bounds on the probability of a successful projection.

Assume that the two-qubit pure states |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle and |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle are initially distributed in the scenario which is showed in Fig. 2. Without loss of generality, suppose θ,η∈(0,π4]𝜃𝜂0𝜋4\theta,\eta\in(0,\frac{\pi}{4}]. A maximally entangled state could be created between Alice and Bob by projecting Clare’s joint system onto the state |φ⟩ket𝜑|\varphi\rangle without any further local operations. Suppose Clare performs a projective measurement in the orthonormal basis {|φk⟩}k=14superscriptsubscriptketsubscript𝜑𝑘𝑘14\{|\varphi_{k}\rangle\}_{k=1}^{4} with p​(φk)𝑝subscript𝜑𝑘p(\varphi_{k}) being the probability of projecting the system into the state |φk⟩ketsubscript𝜑𝑘|\varphi_{k}\rangle and |ϕk⟩A​Bsubscriptketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝐴𝐵|\phi_{k}\rangle_{AB} being the corresponding post-measurement state of Alice and Bob’s joint system.

Firstly, let |φ1⟩ketsubscript𝜑1|\varphi_{1}\rangle be the successful projection such that p​(φ1)𝑝subscript𝜑1p(\varphi_{1}) reaches the upper bound of the projection probability in Eq. (1). In the next step, we try to construct another successful projection state |φ2⟩ketsubscript𝜑2|\varphi_{2}\rangle. The state |φ2⟩ketsubscript𝜑2|\varphi_{2}\rangle should be of the form in Eq. (II). The orthogonality of the projection states |φ2⟩ketsubscript𝜑2|\varphi_{2}\rangle and |φ1⟩ketsubscript𝜑1|\varphi_{1}\rangle requires ⟨φ1|φ2⟩=0inner-productsubscript𝜑1subscript𝜑20\langle\varphi_{1}|\varphi_{2}\rangle=0 which is equivalent to the following constraint

|φ2⟩=(f3​|00⟩+ei​β2​f0​|11⟩)/f02+f32ketsubscript𝜑2subscript𝑓3ket00superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝛽2subscript𝑓0ket11superscriptsubscript𝑓02superscriptsubscript𝑓32\displaystyle|\varphi_{2}\rangle=(f_{3}|00\rangle+e^{i\beta_{2}}f_{0}|11\rangle)/\sqrt{f_{0}^{2}+f_{3}^{2}} (10)

where β2∈[0,2​π)subscript𝛽202𝜋\beta_{2}\in[0,2\pi) is an arbitrary phase and p​(φ2)=sin2⁡2​θ​sin2⁡2​η4​(1+cos⁡2​θ​cos⁡2​η)𝑝subscript𝜑2superscript22𝜃superscript22𝜂412𝜃2𝜂p(\varphi_{2})=\frac{\sin^{2}{2\theta}\sin^{2}{2\eta}}{4(1+\cos{2\theta}\cos{2\eta})}.

A simple calculation shows that there is not a third projection state which is of the form in Eq. (II) and orthogonal to the projections states |φ1⟩ketsubscript𝜑1|\varphi_{1}\rangle and |φ2⟩ketsubscript𝜑2|\varphi_{2}\rangle. The other projection states can be chosen as

|φ3⟩=ketsubscript𝜑3absent\displaystyle|\varphi_{3}\rangle= (f1​|01⟩−ei​β1​f2​|10⟩)/f12+f22,subscript𝑓1ket01superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝛽1subscript𝑓2ket10superscriptsubscript𝑓12superscriptsubscript𝑓22\displaystyle(f_{1}|01\rangle-e^{i\beta_{1}}f_{2}|10\rangle)/\sqrt{f_{1}^{2}+f_{2}^{2}}, (11)
|φ4⟩=ketsubscript𝜑4absent\displaystyle|\varphi_{4}\rangle= (f0​|00⟩−ei​β2​f3​|11⟩)/f02+f32subscript𝑓0ket00superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝛽2subscript𝑓3ket11superscriptsubscript𝑓02superscriptsubscript𝑓32\displaystyle(f_{0}|00\rangle-e^{i\beta_{2}}f_{3}|11\rangle)/\sqrt{f_{0}^{2}+f_{3}^{2}} (12)

with the projection probabilities being p​(φ3)=f14+f24f12+f22𝑝subscript𝜑3superscriptsubscript𝑓14superscriptsubscript𝑓24superscriptsubscript𝑓12superscriptsubscript𝑓22p(\varphi_{3})=\frac{f_{1}^{4}+f_{2}^{4}}{f_{1}^{2}+f_{2}^{2}} and p​(φ4)=f04+f34f02+f32𝑝subscript𝜑4superscriptsubscript𝑓04superscriptsubscript𝑓34superscriptsubscript𝑓02superscriptsubscript𝑓32p(\varphi_{4})=\frac{f_{0}^{4}+f_{3}^{4}}{f_{0}^{2}+f_{3}^{2}}, respectively. The corresponding post-measurement states of Alice and Bob’s joint system are as follows

|ϕ3⟩A​B=subscriptketsubscriptitalic-ϕ3𝐴𝐵absent\displaystyle|\phi_{3}\rangle_{AB}= (f12​|01⟩−e−i​β1​f22​|10⟩)/f14+f24,superscriptsubscript𝑓12ket01superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝛽1superscriptsubscript𝑓22ket10superscriptsubscript𝑓14superscriptsubscript𝑓24\displaystyle(f_{1}^{2}|01\rangle-e^{-i\beta_{1}}f_{2}^{2}|10\rangle)/\sqrt{f_{1}^{4}+f_{2}^{4}}, (13)

(14)

We have figure out a projective measurement for Clare. Two of the projections would directly leave Alice and Bob’s joint system in maximally entangled states while another two leave them in less entangled states. When the latter measurement outcomes are observed, we can concentrate entanglement from the less entangled states by performing local operations on either Alice or Bob’s system.

Let q𝑞q and q′superscript𝑞′q^{{}^{\prime}} be the probabilities that we can concentrate maximally entangled state from |ϕ3⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ3|\phi_{3}\rangle and |ϕ4⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ4|\phi_{4}\rangle by performing the corresponding general measurement on Bob’s qubit, respectively. As we have assumed θ,η∈(0,π4]𝜃𝜂0𝜋4\theta,\eta\in(0,\frac{\pi}{4}], it follows that f0≥f3subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓3f_{0}\geq f_{3}. With out loss of generality, we suppose η≥θ𝜂𝜃\eta\geq\theta which implies f1≥f2subscript𝑓1subscript𝑓2f_{1}\geq f_{2}. By applying Lemma 1, we get

q=2​f24f14+f24,q′=2​f34f04+f34.formulae-sequence𝑞2superscriptsubscript𝑓24superscriptsubscript𝑓14superscriptsubscript𝑓24superscript𝑞′2superscriptsubscript𝑓34superscriptsubscript𝑓04superscriptsubscript𝑓34\displaystyle q=\frac{2f_{2}^{4}}{f_{1}^{4}+f_{2}^{4}},q^{{}^{\prime}}=\frac{2f_{3}^{4}}{f_{0}^{4}+f_{3}^{4}}.

In general, the maximally entangled resource can be created between Alice and Bob with probability

PM​S=subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆absent\displaystyle P_{MS}= p​(φ1)+p​(φ2)+p​(φ3)∗q+p​(φ4)∗q′=2​sin2⁡θ.𝑝subscript𝜑1𝑝subscript𝜑2𝑝subscript𝜑3𝑞𝑝subscript𝜑4superscript𝑞′2superscript2𝜃\displaystyle p(\varphi_{1})+p(\varphi_{2})+p(\varphi_{3})*q+p(\varphi_{4})*q^{{}^{\prime}}=2\sin^{2}{\theta}.

Note that 2​sin2⁡θ2superscript2𝜃2\sin^{2}{\theta} also equals to the optimal probability PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}) that the maximally entangled state can be concentrated in the scenario where the resource |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle is directly prepared between Alice and Bob. Thus, we have PM​S=PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{MS}=P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}).

Similarly, we get PM​S=PE​(Φη)subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{MS}=P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta}) for the case θ≥η𝜃𝜂\theta\geq\eta. Thus, the maximally entangled resource can be concentrated from the scenario in Fig. 2 with probability PM​S=min⁡{PE​(Φθ),PE​(Φη)}subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{MS}=\min\{P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}),P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta})\}. In fact, this is the optimal entanglement concentration rate for the scenario. It is obvious that PM​Ssubscript𝑃𝑀𝑆P_{MS} should be not greater than both PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}) and PE​(Φη)subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta}). Otherwise, say PM​S>PE​(Φθ)subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃P_{MS}>P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}), maximally entangled resource would be concentrated from the bipartitely distributed resource |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle with probability PM​Ssubscript𝑃𝑀𝑆P_{MS} by locally preparing an ancilla state |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle and applying above strategy, which contradicts with Lemma 1.

By performing the projective measurement on Clare’s joint system, no further local operation is needed when any of the two successful projections is observed. Maximally entangled resources will be directly created between Alice and Bob with probability sin2⁡2​θ​sin2⁡2​η2​(1−cos2⁡2​θ​cos2⁡2​η)superscript22𝜃superscript22𝜂21superscript22𝜃superscript22𝜂\frac{\sin^{2}{2\theta}\sin^{2}{2\eta}}{2(1-\cos^{2}{2\theta}\cos^{2}{2\eta})}. Assume that the classical communication channel is liable. It is possible to establish an efficient classical communication agreement for telling Bob to take the corresponding action.

Therefore, we have constructed a protocol for extending the distance of entanglement distribution, which is optimal in perspective of entanglement concentration rate and efficient in perspective LOCC complexity. With this, we have proved the following theorem which is the main result of this section.

Theorem 1.

Suppose two two-qubit pure states |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle and |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle are initially distributed in the scenario showed in Fig. 2. Firstly, apply a projective measurement in the orthonormal baisi {|φk}k=14\{|\varphi_{k}\}_{k=1}^{4}, which is defined in Eqs. (9-12), on Clare’s joint system. Secondly, selectively perform local operation on Bob’s system according to Clare’s measurement outcome. Then, maximally entangled resource could be created between Alice and Bob with probability PM​S=min⁡{PE​(Φθ),PE​(Φη)}subscript𝑃𝑀𝑆subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜃subscript𝑃𝐸subscriptΦ𝜂P_{MS}=\min\{P_{E}(\Phi_{\theta}),P_{E}(\Phi_{\eta})\}. This protocol is efficient in perspectives of both entanglement concentration rate and LOCC complexity.

II.1 Criteria for optimal projective measurements in perspective of entanglement concentration rate

For the scenario depicted in Fig. 2, the projective measurement in the standard Bell basis is also able to achieve the optimal entanglement concentration rate BY00 . Thus, the optimal projective measurement for Clare’s joint system is not unique in perspective of entanglement concentration rate. However, not all of projective measurements could achieve that goal. For example, it is impossible to obtain entanglement between Alice and Bob by projecting Clare’s system into separable states.

Hence, it is a practical problem to verify whether a projective measurements is able to concentrate entanglement from the scenario with the optimal rate. The following theorem gives a criteria for such measurements.

Theorem 2.

We consider a scenario with the states |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle and |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle, which is showed in Fig. 2. With out loss of generality, suppose θ,η∈(0,π4]𝜃𝜂0𝜋4\theta,\eta\in(0,\frac{\pi}{4}] and θ≤η𝜃𝜂\theta\leq\eta. Suppose P≡{Pk}k=14𝑃superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑘14P\equiv\{P_{k}\}_{k=1}^{4} is a projective measurement on ℋ2⊗2superscriptsubscriptℋ2tensor-productabsent2\mathcal{H}_{2}^{\otimes 2} where Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} are projectors. With assistance of LOCC, the projective measurement P𝑃P on Clare’s joint system is able to achieve the optimal entanglement concentration rate if and only if

∑k=14(t​r​(T1⊗T2​Pk))2+sin2⁡2​θ​|t​r​(|0⟩​⟨1|⊗T2​Pk)|2=cos⁡2​θsuperscriptsubscript𝑘14superscript𝑡𝑟tensor-productsubscript𝑇1subscript𝑇2subscript𝑃𝑘2superscript22𝜃superscript𝑡𝑟tensor-productket0bra1subscript𝑇2subscript𝑃𝑘22𝜃\sum_{k=1}^{4}\sqrt{(tr(T_{1}\otimes T_{2}P_{k}))^{2}+\sin^{2}{2\theta}|tr(|0\rangle\langle 1|\otimes T_{2}P_{k})|^{2}}=\cos{2\theta} (15)

With simple calculations, it shows that both the projective measurement in standard Bell basis and the one we proposed in this section fulfill the criteria.

III The upper bound for the scenario with different general pure states

In this section, we exploit a more general scenario where different general pure states are prepared and general measurements are consider. Suppose a general bipartite pure state |ψA​B⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝐴𝐵|\psi_{AB}\rangle is shared by Alice and Clare while |ψC​B⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝐶𝐵|\psi_{CB}\rangle is shared by Clare and Bob. We analyze the measurement outcome which leaves Alice and Bob in a maximally entangled state without any further local operations. We refer such measurement outcome as a successful measurement outcome. The scenario is depicted in Fig. 3. Note that an arbitrary maximally entangled state can be written as |ΩU⟩≡(U⊗I)​|Ω⟩ketsubscriptΩ𝑈tensor-product𝑈𝐼ketΩ|\Omega_{U}\rangle\equiv(U\otimes I)|\Omega\rangle, where U𝑈U is a local unitary on ℋdsubscriptℋ𝑑\mathcal{H}_{d} and |Ω⟩=1d​∑k=1d|k⟩​|k⟩ketΩ1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑑ket𝑘ket𝑘|\Omega\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}\sum_{k=1}^{d}|k\rangle|k\rangle is the standard maximally entangled state.

The probability of observing a successful measurement outcome is variant for different U𝑈U. Theorem 3 gives an upper bound on the probability, which is the main result of this section. To prove Theorem 3, we need two lemmas. Lemma 4 is concluded from Wolf’s lecture notes MW12 . Lemma 5 is a generalization of a mathematical theorem which is proved by Lewis AS96 . We denote λ↓​(A)subscript𝜆↓𝐴\lambda_{\downarrow}(A) for the collum vector of operator A𝐴A’s eigenvalues in the nonincreasing order and λ↑​(A)subscript𝜆↑𝐴\lambda_{\uparrow}(A) for that in the nondecreasing order.

Lemma 4.

Suppose |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle is a bipartite pure state of the joint quantum system A⊗Btensor-product𝐴𝐵A\otimes B. Let ρA≡t​rB​(|ψ⟩​⟨ψ|)subscript𝜌𝐴𝑡subscript𝑟𝐵ket𝜓bra𝜓\rho_{A}\equiv tr_{B}(|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|) be the density operator of the subsystem A𝐴A. Suppose ρAsubscript𝜌𝐴\rho_{A} could be expressed as a convex combination ρA=∑iλi​ρisubscript𝜌𝐴subscript𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{A}=\sum_{i}\lambda_{i}\rho_{i} where λi>0subscript𝜆𝑖0\lambda_{i}>0, ∑iλi=1subscript𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖1\sum_{i}\lambda_{i}=1 and ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} are density operators on ℋAsubscriptℋ𝐴\mathcal{H}_{A}. Then, there is a quantum measurement operation on system B𝐵B, say T={Ti:ℬ​(ℋℬ)→ℬ​(ℋℬ)}𝑇conditional-setsubscript𝑇𝑖→ℬsubscriptℋℬℬsubscriptℋℬT=\{T_{i}:\mathcal{B(H_{B})}\rightarrow\mathcal{B(H_{B})}\}, such that

λi​ρi=t​rB​[(I⊗Ti)​(|ψ⟩​⟨ψ|)].subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖𝑡subscript𝑟𝐵delimited-[]tensor-product𝐼subscript𝑇𝑖ket𝜓bra𝜓\displaystyle\lambda_{i}\rho_{i}=tr_{B}[(I\otimes T_{i})(|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|)]. (16)

The parameter λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} can be interpreted as the probability of observing the measurement outcome i𝑖i. The upper bound of λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} is as follows

Lemma 5.

For Hermitian operators A𝐴A and B𝐵B,

t​r​(A​B)≥λ↑​(A)T​λ↓​(B)𝑡𝑟𝐴𝐵subscript𝜆↑superscript𝐴𝑇subscript𝜆↓𝐵\displaystyle tr(AB)\geq\lambda_{\uparrow}(A)^{T}\lambda_{\downarrow}(B) (18)

with equality if and only if there is a unitary operator U𝑈U such that U†​A​U=d​i​a​g​(λ↑​(A))superscript𝑈†𝐴𝑈𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜆↑𝐴U^{\dagger}AU=diag(\lambda_{\uparrow}(A)) and U†​B​U=d​i​a​g​(λ↓​(B))superscript𝑈†𝐵𝑈𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜆↓𝐵U^{\dagger}BU=diag(\lambda_{\downarrow}(B)).

Theorem 3.

pi≤‖ρA​B−12​ρU​ρA​B−12‖∞−1.subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝐴𝐵12subscript𝜌𝑈superscriptsubscript𝜌𝐴𝐵121\displaystyle p_{i}\leq\parallel\rho_{AB}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\rho_{U}\rho_{AB}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\parallel^{-1}_{\infty}. (20)

where the inverse operator is defined on the corresponding support space. IV Conclusion and discussion

In this paper, we have exploited the basic configuration of quantum repeaters in perspectives of both entanglement concentration rate and LOCC complexity. For the scenario with two different two-qubit pure states, we constructed a protocol to concentrate entanglement. The protocol is optimal in perspective entanglement concentration rate and efficient in perspective LOCC complexity. We also find a criteria for the projective measurement to achieve the optimal entanglement concentration rate. For the scenario where general pure states are prepared and general measurements are considered, we get the upper bound on the probability of a successful measurement outcome which produces a maximally entangled state between Alice and Bob without any further local operations.

The protocol is composed of two steps. Firstly, Clare performs a measurement operation. Secondly, based on Clare’s measurement outcome, Bob chooses the corresponding strategy; namely, Bob does not do any further local operations or performs the corresponding general measurements. In general, the protocol can concentrate entanglement from the scenario with the optimal rate. We reduced the LOCC complexity via the strategy that no further local operation was needed if maximally entangled state could be created between Alice and Bob when a measurement outcome was observed by Clare.

For the scenario with different two-qubit states |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle and |Φη⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜂|\Phi_{\eta}\rangle, we constructed a projective measurement such that maximally entangled state could be created after two of the four measurement outcomes. Such measurement outcomes could be observed with probability sin2⁡2​θ​sin2⁡2​η2​(1−cos2⁡2​θ​cos2⁡2​η)superscript22𝜃superscript22𝜂21superscript22𝜃superscript22𝜂\frac{\sin^{2}{2\theta}\sin^{2}{2\eta}}{2(1-\cos^{2}{2\theta}\cos^{2}{2\eta})}. If the states for the scenario are same, say |Φθ⟩ketsubscriptΦ𝜃|\Phi_{\theta}\rangle, we can construct a projective measurement with three successful projections to produce maximally entangled states without any further local operations. The corresponding probability is sin2⁡2​θ​(3+cos2⁡2​θ)4​(1+cos2⁡2​θ)superscript22𝜃3superscript22𝜃41superscript22𝜃\frac{\sin^{2}{2\theta}(3+\cos^{2}{2\theta})}{4(1+\cos^{2}{2\theta})}.
